clinical_study.brief_title: Pyridostigmine and Its Effects on Autonomic Modulation in Diabetic Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Pyridostigmine and Its Effects on Autonomic Modulation in Diabetic Patients With Autonomic Neuropathy

lead_sponsor.agency: Hospital de Clinicas de Porto Alegre

clinical_study.source: Hospital de Clinicas de Porto Alegre

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of the study is to determine if pyridostigmine bromide improves heart rate variability of type 2 diabetes mellitus subjects with cardiovascular autonomic neuropathy.

detailed_description.textblock: The reduced heart rate variability is associated with increased risk of death in patients with diabetes mellitus. Cholinesterase inhibition with pyridostigmine bromide increases heart rate variability in normal individuals and congestive heart failure subjects but its effects on patients with diabetes mellitus is unknown. Based on those evidences, we will test if the short-term administration of pyridostigmine bromide increases heart rate variability in patients with diabetes mellitus.

primary_outcome.measure: autonomic modulation assessed by heart rate variability

arm_group.description: If a subject is randomized to placebo, he will receive placebo pills 3 times daily for 1 day.

intervention.description: Pills containing 30 mg of Pyridostigmine will be orally administered 3 times daily for 1 day.
If subject is randomized to placebo, placebo pills will give 30 mg orally 3 times daily for 2 days

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- diabetes mellitus
Exclusion Criteria:
- myocardial infarction
- acute ischemic syndromes
- second or third degree atrioventricular block
- active alcoholism
- thyroid dysfunction
- chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
- history of intolerance to pyridostigmine.
